episodes.title: Álvaro Enrigue: Sudden Death
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Álvaro Enrigue's Sudden Death is the wild tale of a tennis match between the poet Francisco de Quevedo and the artist Caravaggio that transcends time and involves other historically transformative, and often combative, figures. Enrigue, who calls his impulse to write "visceral and erratic," was angered into starting this book by the 2008 financial crisis.

episodes.title: Rachel Cusk: Transit
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Rachel Cusk's novel Transit is the second in a planned trilogy. Cusk believes that humans have an innate grasp of form, a gift that makes us story-tellers. But the stories we tell ourselves can become traps.

episodes.title: Steve Erickson: Shadowbahn
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: In Erickson's intense, absorbing novel, the Twin Towers suddenly re-appear in the Dakota Badlands. This road novel is a trip through a phantom country where the American dream was never realized.

episodes.title: Michael Tolkin: NK3
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: The North Koreans have tested a weapon called NK3, a weaponized nano-bacterium designed to confuse South Koreans. The test has spread around the world. As a result, the world has lost its memory.

episodes.title: Ron Padgett: Collected Poems
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Padgett's poems stand in for the poems written by a bus driver in the Jim Jarmusch movie Paterson. Padgett experiences writing poetry as a natural activity, rather like brushing his teeth.

episodes.title: Ottessa Moshfegh: Homesick for Another World (Part II)
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: In the second half of our conversation with Ottessa Moshfegh, the author discusses her discomfort in this world but admits that there is a touch of self-parody in the title of this collection of stories.

episodes.title: Ottessa Moshfegh: Homesick for Another World (Part I)
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: In the first of two conversations with Ottessa Moshfegh, the author reveals that she doesn't feel comfortable in this world. Her characters long for another world, as does Moshfegh.

episodes.title: Lynne Tillman: The Complete Madame Realism and Other Stories
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Lynne Tillman's The Complete Madame Realism and Other Stories, is a unique blend of short fiction, essays, and philosophical musings that defy categorization.

episodes.title: Don DeLillo: Zero K
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: In Don DeLillo's latest novel, Zero K, the practice of cryonics or freezing oneself to be awakened later, is in full, but secret swing.

episodes.title: Colson Whitehead: The Underground Railroad
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Colson Whitehead's new great American novel depicts a real underground railroad that transports a fugitive slave to stops that defy time and history, highlighting the daily struggles of black people, past and present.

episodes.title: Patrick Ness: A Monster Calls
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Patrick Ness' A Monster Calls – about a boy facing tremendous conflict with a bully at school, well-meaning inattentive teachers, and a dying mother – was actually already a story begun by another writer, who died before finishing it.

episodes.title: Rabih Alameddine: The Angel of History
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Rabih Alameddine's The Angel of History takes place as much in the protagonist's head as it does in a psych ward where he checks himself in for a bit of rest while he battles the voices in his head.

episodes.title: Mitch Sisskind: Do Not Be a Gentleman When You say Goodnight
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Mitch Sisskind's Do Not Be a Gentleman When You Say Goodnight is a distillation of nearly fifty years of brilliant comic writing.

episodes.title: Peter Orner: Am I Alone Here?
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: When novelist Peter Orner's father died, he found himself unable to write. At the same time, his marriage fell apart. He consoled himself by reading and started to write responses to the literature that gave him comfort.

episodes.title: Kate Tempest: The Bricks that Built the Houses
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Rapper, poet, playwright and now novelist, Kate Tempest always knew she would write The Bricks that Built the Houses as an accompaniment to the characters in her record Everybody Down. (Rebroadcast)

episodes.title: TC Boyle: The Terranauts
episodes.author: KCRW, KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: TC Boyle's The Terranauts centers around eight earth explorers who lock themselves up in E2, a biodome created to mimic earth and test the viability of a self-sustained environment. But what happens between the eight terranauts and their mission control has a bigger impact on sustainability than science had counted on.

episodes.title: Tessa Hadley: The Past
episodes.author: KCRW, KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Tessa Hadley's book, The Past, has at its center a summer vacation home, and the four middle-aged siblings who come together to decide whether to sell it or not.

episodes.title: Ann Patchett: Commonwealth
episodes.author: KCRW, KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Ann Patchett's latest novel, Commonwealth, follows fifty-two years in the life of a large family. The idea of the book came to her because as a bookstore owner, she saw that what was missing from the shelves was the story of a big, modern family.

episodes.title: Jonathan Safran Foer: Here I Am
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: The hero of Here I Am is a pun-loving television writer who is pummeled by the loss of everything he values.  This novel expands a family crisis into a global crisis which threatens the state of Israel.

episodes.title: Nicholson Baker: Substitute
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Nicholson Baker's Substitute: Going to School with a Thousand Kids was born of a desire to write a book articulating his theories about education – theories based on having had kids in school. Realizing his premise was weak, as he'd never been a teacher, he embarked on the adventure of a lifetime by becoming a substitute teacher.

episodes.title: Nadja Spiegelman: I'm Supposed to Protect You from All This
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Since memory is not only malleable but unreliable, which version of the truth will prevail?

episodes.title: Jacqueline Woodson: Another Brooklyn
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Another Brooklyn, award-winning Young Adult novelist Jacqueline Woodson's first novel for adults in twenty years, tells the story of childhood friends as they grow into women.

episodes.title: Marisa Silver: Little Nothing
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: An ugly young dwarf girl transforms first into a beauty, then into a tall woman, then into a wolf.

episodes.title: Affinity Konar: Mischling
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: In Auschwitz, the infamous Dr. Mengele conducted horrifying physical and psychological experiments on concentration camp prisoners. Affinity Konar's Mischling (meaning mixed blood) is the story of twin sisters who find themselves imprisoned in Dr. Mengele's "zoo."

episodes.title: Adam Fitzgerald: George Washington
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Adam Fitzgerald's poetry in George Washington: Poems comes across as playful while exploring the concept of Americana and what that means.

episodes.title: Krys Lee: How I Became a North Korean
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Krys Lee's first novel dramatizes boundaries and borders – not just political ones but those that complicate human relationships.

episodes.title: Joe McGinniss Jr: Carousel Court
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: A married couple wind up in a wasteland of foreclosed houses and abandoned homes.

episodes.title: Tom McCarthy: Satin Island
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Tom McCarthy's Satin Island features a protagonist who, as his company's corporate anthropologist, has been given the enormous task of compiling a report summing up the modern era.

episodes.title: Tom Lutz: Drinking Mare's Milk on the Roof of the World
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: In his travels to more than 100 countries – some dangerous, some surprisingly not – Tom Lutz finds that the more places he goes, the more the world leaves him a little bit lost.

episodes.title: Michelle Latiolais: She
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Neither a novel nor a collection of stories, the "fictions" in She  weave together a composite view of Los Angeles.

episodes.title: Constantine Phipps: What You Want
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: A tale of the ordinary, everyday quest for contentedness -- written entirely in heroic couplets.

episodes.title: Vivian Gornick: The Odd Woman and the City
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Vivian Gornick's memoir The Odd Woman and the City takes us on a tour of a life that is lived by walking, observing and talking. Gornick keeps her eyes open, and does she ever have a mouth on her!

episodes.title: Geoff Dyer: White Sands
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Paradoxically, Geoff Dyer begins his attempt to locate America by first traveling to Tahiti. There, he discovers that Gauguin’s vision of it no longer exists – if it ever really did. Can he find the soul of America in its landscapes?

episodes.title: Louise Erdrich: LaRose, Part II
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: In part two of this conversation about LaRose – Louise Erdrich's novel about an act of restorative justice that tests the boundaries between two families – the discussion explores the non-linear form the novel moves in towards seeking balance and resolution.

episodes.title: Louise Erdrich: LaRose, Part I
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: In Louise Erdrich's LaRose, a terrible tragedy forces two families to resort to a form of traditional "restorative justice" in which one son must be given to replace the loss of another. Erdrich talks about this act as an attempt at restoring balance in a tight knit community where healing can take generations.

episodes.title: Joyce Carol Oates: The Man Without a Shadow
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Joyce Carol Oates raises questions about memory – ethics, what it means to love, identity, and the ability to engage, and takes us on a trip down memory lane with a reading from a previous memoir recounting her favorite bad-for-you childhood foods.

episodes.title: A. Scott Berg: Max Perkins
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: A. Scott Berg's Max Perkins: Editor of Genius is the biography of Maxwell Perkins, a long time Scribner editor who worked with the likes of Hemingway, Fitzgerald and Thomas Wolfe.

episodes.title: John Keene: Counternarratives
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: John Keene takes classic American narratives and stands them on their heads. In North and South American tales, he writes about the "others" (Indians, blacks, queers) to re-examine stories we think we know.

episodes.title: John D'Agata: The Making of the American Essay
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Despite 20 years of study, John D'Agata believes that we're still in the "Wild West" of coming to terms with the essay, its long heritage and its creation.

episodes.title: Valeria Luiselli: The Story of My Teeth
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Originally commissioned to write a novel for Jumex, a Mexican beverage company and supporter of the arts, Luiselli instead chose to write a novel for Jumex's factory workers.

episodes.title: Garth Greenwell: What Belongs to You
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Greenwell's first novel examines the relationship between an American teacher in Bulgaria with a male prostitute.

episodes.title: David Means: Hystopia
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: After four acclaimed short story collections, Means' first novel takes on the Vietnam War.

episodes.title: Helen Macdonald: H Is for Hawk
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Helen Macdonald's new book is her account of working through her grief over her father's death by adopting and training a goshawk.

episodes.title: Christopher Sorrentino: The Fugitives
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: The characters of Christopher Sorrentino's novel are unreliable narrators. They're liars who hide the truth, not only from themselves but ultimately from the reader.

episodes.title: Greg Jackson: Prodigals
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Greg Jackson's new collection of eight stories follows the lives of youngish people of privilege on their journey to deconstruct just what their destination is supposed to be. But his characters might be running up against the mystery of themselves.

episodes.title: Brian Blanchfield: Proxies
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Blanchfield's essays reveal truths about a queer poet in the post-AIDS era.

episodes.title: Dana Spiotta: Innocents and Others
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Dana Spiotta's Innocents and Others tells the feminist story of how women make do in a male-dominated world through two female filmmaker best friends, and a third, troubled woman adept at beguiling powerful Hollywood men.

episodes.title: David Remnick and Deborah Treisman on fiction in the New Yorker
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: David Remnick and Deborah Treisman, editor and fiction editor, take us through the fiction at the New Yorker and how it has changed over the years.

episodes.title: Joshua Cohen: Book of Numbers
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Joshua Cohen's The Book of Numbers  follows the rise of the Internet through a protagonist he modeled after some of the web's biggest shapers, including Google's Sergey Brin, but mostly Apple's Steve Jobs.

episodes.title: Elizabeth McKenzie: The Portable Veblen
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Elizabeth McKenzie's half screwball romantic comedy and half critique of the conspicuous consumption of the leisure class, featuring a heroine named after the depressive American economist Thorstein Veblen and a cast that includes advice-giving squirrels.

episodes.title: Mark de Silva: Square Wave
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Philosopher Mark de Silva's debut novel shows what a novel can do when it goes off the beaten track.

episodes.title: Darryl Pinckney: Black Deutschland
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Darryl Pinckney talks about the attraction of leaving America to discover how to be an African-American in America.

episodes.title: Ryan Gattis: All Involved
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Ryan Gattis' new book, All Involved, is really a reconstitution of the L.A. riots from a person who wasn't there.

episodes.title: Larissa MacFarquhar: Strangers Drowning
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Larissa MacFarquhar writes about do-gooders who practice effective altruism. They don't care what others think of their extreme choices. They care about being effective.

episodes.title: Edmund de Waal: The White Road
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Edmund de Waal takes us on a vast journey into the history and heart, skin and bones of porcelain.

episodes.title: Bruce Bauman: Broken Sleep
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Bruce Bauman's new novel is like a family with everyone, including the reader, struggling to find a place, a home, a sense of community.

episodes.title: Supplication: Selected Poems of John Wieners
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Poets and editors CAConrad, Robert Dewhurst, and Joshua Beckman talk both about groundbreaking, boldly gay poet/activist, John Wieners, and about the process of compiling and honoring such a prolific poet with the selected works book.

episodes.title: Rick Moody: Hotels of North America
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Hotel reviews that really, become reviews on life.

episodes.title: Salman Rushdie: Two Years Eight Months and Twenty-Eight Nights
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Salman Rushdie's version of The Arabian Nights, his attempt to understand what the through-line of the collection of classic tales is and partly as a portrait of the human race and its salvation. (Repeat)

episodes.title: Paul Murray: The Mark and the Void
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Paul Murray's comic novel dramatizes an economic crisis in his native Ireland, one that imperils the vitality of Dublin's culture.

episodes.title: Eileen Myles: I Must Be Living Twice
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Poet, fiction writer, essayist and dramatist Eileen Myles on success, the relevancy of poetry and surviving as a poet

episodes.title: Isabel Allende: The Japanese Lover
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Allende brings her emotional wisdom to the love lives of three generations of post World War II Asian and Jewish characters.

episodes.title: Sandra Cisneros: A House of My Own
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Sandra Cisneros, now in her sixties, looks back at her journey to find her voice, in a candid memoir woven from prose, photographs, and essays.

episodes.title: Jonathan Franzen: Purity
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Jonathan Franzen's latest book is an exploration of intensely intimate relationships and the inevitability of their destructive effects.

episodes.title: Gary Indiana: I Can Give You Anything but Love
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: The outlandish and unguarded Gary Indiana has written what can be described as an "anti-memoir." He doesn't like memoirs but has written one himself, partly because he has lived a real life all over the world: he actually has something to write about.

episodes.title: Mary Karr: The Art of Memoir
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Is it common practice to lie in a memoir? Not for accomplished memoirists, according to Mary Karr. The Art of Memoir, in part a how-to book, distills 30 years of teaching and writing memoir.

episodes.title: Joy Williams: The Visiting Privilege
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: The writer's writer, Joy Williams, has written a book that spans her body of work – from familiar stories to new ones, showcases her deep, natural understanding of the process of writing.

episodes.title: Patrick deWitt: Undermajordomo Minor
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Patrick deWitt's latest book follows his penchant for building humiliation into his novels.

episodes.title: Bill Clegg: Did You Ever Have a Family
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Bill Clegg makes the transition from memoirist to novelist. His book and its title are a statement on the kindness of strangers and the necessity to fashion one's own family.

episodes.title: Ann Beattie: The State We're In
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: In The State We're In: Maine Stories, Ann Beattie deftly and effortlessly takes the ingredients that make up short stories and shakes them up to create something new and beautiful.

episodes.title: Bonnie Nadzam and Dale Jamieson: Love in the Anthropocene
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Fiction writer Bonnie Nadzam and environmental philosopher, Dale Jamieson, worked together to write Love in the Anthropocene, a collection of five short stories that describe a very near future in which nature as we know it no longer exists.

episodes.title: Dodie Bellamy: When the Sick Rule the World
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: In this collection of prose pieces, Bellamy explodes the essay form into poetry, personal memoire and literary analysis

episodes.title: William T. Vollmann: The Dying Grass, Part II
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: The Dying Grass: A Novel of the Nez Perce War is the fifth book in Vollman's seven-book series about loss and transformation of the North American continent, this novel dramatizes a power grab disguised as a race war between Native Americans and settlers.

episodes.title: William T. Vollmann: The Dying Grass, Part I
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: The rise of corporate America begins with the ruthless acquisition of Indian land in this massively researched epic which evokes the language, the food, and the lost customs of the Nez Perce.  This is the first of two conversations about William Vollman’s novel of the 1877 war that destroyed the Nez Perce.

episodes.title: Allison Green: The Ghosts Who Travel with Me
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: A conversation with the author and Emily Goldman of Ooligan Press.

episodes.title: Louisa Hall: Speak
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Louisa Hall's novel Speak considers the Alan Turing test:  how do we know if what we are communicating with via machine is human?

episodes.title: Mira Gonzalez and Tao Lin: Selected Tweets
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Mira Gonzalez and Tao Lin's Selected Tweets is a compendium of tweets -- often dark and dispairing, but also bitingly funny -- written over the course of ten years, sometimes under their own names, sometimes using assumed names.

episodes.title: E. L. Doctorow: Homer & Langley
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: In this comic and affecting novel based on the lives of the Collyer brothers — one a blind pianist, the other a hoarder and inventor — Doctorow creates an ironic allegory of modern America.

episodes.title: Harper Lee: Go Set a Watchman
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Michael Silverblatt in conversation with Bookworm producer Connie Alvarez  about the recent book by the late author. Harper Lee died today at the age of 89.

episodes.title: Linda Rosenkrantz: Talk
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: In 1965, a young Linda Rosenkrantz had the novel idea to tape record her friends on the beach in East Hampton. The result was Talk, in which anything could become a subject for conversation – it was all discussed.

episodes.title: Christian Kracht: Imperium
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Christian Kracht's Imperium: A Fiction of the South Seas is a satirical parable that sees fanaticism as the root of German culture and imperialist culture in general.

episodes.title: Amy Gerstler: Scattered at Sea
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Amy Gerstler's new book of poems is an exploration of getting lost, the unknown, mortality and remembrance.

episodes.title: Vendela Vida: The Diver's Clothes Lie Empty
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Vendela Vida's new novel is a story of identity, a recurring mystery in her work. We get to the bottom of why identity is her obsession.

episodes.title: Aleksandar Hemon: The Making of Zombie Wars
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: This darkly nihilistic book masquerading as a comedy is as much a commentary on society as it is the story of a bad script-writer.

episodes.title: Alan Cheuse: Prayers for the Living
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: The "voice of NPR book reviews" takes a singular opportunity – the discussion of his own novel with KCRW's bookworm, Michael Silverblatt.

episodes.title: Maggie Nelson: The Argonauts
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: The Argonauts is a work of "auto-theory" in which theory is put to the test against life experience.

episodes.title: Atticus Lish: Preparation for the Next Life
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Atticus Lish's debut novel won the 2015 PEN/Faulkner Award for First Fiction, demonstrating that he waited 40 years to become a natural.

episodes.title: Valeria Luiselli: Faces in the Crowd
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Valeria Luiselli's first novel reminds us of what it's like to be young and in love with literature.

episodes.title: Per Petterson, Ethan Nosowsky and Geir Berdahl on Publishing
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: We talk to author Per Petterson, editor Ethan Nosowsky, and publisher Geir Berdahl about the what it takes to bring a book to life and about the changing world of publishing.

episodes.title: Thomas McGuane: Crow Fair
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Thomas McGuane's new book of stories is a demonstration model of his verbal surprises and his deep insight into his characters.

episodes.title: Per Petterson: I Refuse
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Per Petterson's I Refuse is a beautiful and lyrical symphony of sadness, grief and loss.

episodes.title: Kazuo Ishiguro: The Buried Giant
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Kazuo Ishiguro starts the interview about his new book as a look at the concept of societal memory.

episodes.title: Luis Alberto Urrea: Tijuana Book of the Dead, and The Water Museum
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: The border between poetry and fiction is dismantled when the poet/author is Luis Alberto Urrea.

episodes.title: David Vann: Aquarium
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: In talking about his new novel, David Vann tells us how the characters were born of staring for hours at different delicate fish until they revealed who he was supposed to write about.

episodes.title: Charles Baxter and the 'Hidden Bookshelf'
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Charles Baxter takes us through the pleasure of discovering books for what might be called the "hidden bookshelf."

episodes.title: Charles Baxter: There's Something I  Want You to Do
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Charles Baxter examines the elements of virtue and vice in his new collection of short stories.

episodes.title: Rachel Kushner: The Strange Case of Rachel K
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Rachel Kushner talks about the earliest impulses that inspired her first novel Telex from Cuba. She wanted a new concept of time, she needed to find a voice to create that highly subjective and changeable thing--the past.

episodes.title: Claudia Rankine: The Racial Imaginary
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: The discussion takes up writers who write about the racial "other." Can every writer do it successfully? Are there writers who shouldn't or can't? When is it appropriate and necessary?

episodes.title: Claudia Rankine: Citizen, An American Lyric
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: In discussing Claudia Rankine's Citizen, an American Lyric, we discuss the way racism catches us all.

episodes.title: Joyce Carol Oates: The Sacrifice
episodes.author: KCRW, Michael Silverblatt
episodes.summary: Joyce Carol Oates shapes a novel from the Tawana Brawley scandal of the 1980's.
